Federal student loan forgiveness and repayment programs have been in existence since the National Defense Education Act of 1958. These programs offer borrowers the opportunity to have their student loan debt forgiven or repaid in exchange for service in specific professions or occupations. Currently, there are over 50 federal loan forgiveness and repayment programs available. Loan forgiveness and repayment programs have been created by the federal government to forgive, cancel, or discharge student loan debt in exchange for service in certain professions. Over 50 programs are authorized, with approximately 30 operational as of October 1, 2017. Benefits are often tied to public service or specific occupations, but are increasingly offered as part of income-driven repayment plans. Loan forgiveness benefits are now offered in income-driven student loan repayment plans to incentivize public service or specific professions. These programs aim to provide debt relief to borrowers who have not fully repaid their student loans after an extended period of time. Loan forgiveness benefits and loan repayment benefits provide debt relief to borrowers of federal student loans who enter public service or specific professions, or repay their loans through an income-driven repayment plan. Other forms of debt relief include discharge for disability, death, school closure, false certification, unauthorized loans, unpaid refunds, successful defense to repayment, and bankruptcy discharge. The NDSL program, established in response to the Soviet Union's Sputnik satellite launch in 1957, provided loan forgiveness to borrowers as a national security measure to improve education programs. The NDSL program was established to enhance national security by developing the skills of young men and women through low-interest loans for college students. It included a student loan forgiveness component aimed at increasing the number and quality of teachers in U.S. schools, with benefits targeted at those teaching in schools with low-income students or students with disabilities. Loan forgiveness was also available to individuals serving in Head Start programs.
